description:
I was here to meet up with friends and decided to end the night with a few cocktails before bed. The biggest draw to this bar is the eclectic group of people you'll meet at the bar and the friendly bartenders.

You will enjoy a relaxed environment with an impressive backdrop of artwork of the San Francisco Bay Bridge, an open space with a rich, modern palette, and a great dining experience. Located in the world's largest hotel lobby, If you want a signature cocktail, nice appetizers or just meet some cool people this is the place to go if you're in the area.
author: Tracey M.

description:
We stayed at the Hyatt Recently and decide to stop by here for a late night drink before heading black to our room. We had looked at the happy hours offerings and nothing seemed that appealing or heavily discounted so we had skipped happy hours and opted to go elsewhere priory to dinner.

We were there during last calls and ordered a Karl the Fog and a Bourbon Smash. The drinks took awhile to come and when it did, we realized why. The Karl the Fog is quite a spectacle, it came with a large round block of ice (not the cool clear kind you'd find at a hip bar) and a lid. When the waitress sat it down, she asked if we were ready and lifted the lid and a wisp of smokey cloud starting dissipating out of glass. For $1 more than than Bourbon smash, it was definitely worth it. It was a strong and super smokey drink, but tasty. Bourbon Smash was forgettable. I'd return just to get the Karl the Fog again though.
author: Linh H.

description:
I was staying at this hotel for a conference and at one lunch and one dinner at Eclipse Kitchen and Bar. I sat at the bar both times. I was greeted promptly and felt attended to throughout my meals. I made some friends during dinner while watching some Thursday night football games that were also hotel guests. 

The quality of the food was fantastic. I had a burger for one meal and fish tacos for another and was satisfied and would recommend both. The food was good portions and came out in a timely manner. I mean, you expect it to take some time, and that's fine, but I also went at smart dining times when the kitchen probably wasn't too busy. 

They had a good variety of drinks and even let me sample a few specials they were trying for an event. I appreciated the free test beverage and friendly servers.

There are a million places to go and eat nearby but I wouldn't could this place out. It's got a great staff, great food selection and cozy atmosphere for being in a hotel lobby.
author: Gabby G.

description: Pretty pricey but it was good. Pot stickers were delicious! There have a good happy hour selection but not very good discounts.
author: Maddie S.

description:
Came here for happy hours. Got the brussels spout chips and cappuccino. The cappuccino was not bad. Wish the cup was more full. The chips were interesting. It came with a sauce to dip. The atmosphere was interesting and nice.

Lots of charging station. Great place for drinks.
author: Denise W.

description: Surprisingly good food given that it is a hotel restaurant. It has great views of the beautiful big atrium. Everything we ate was pretty good. My fave was the soba noodles and pot de creme. Efficient and friendly service.
author: Sunil R.

description: Decor and seating is unique and beautiful. Food and service doesn't match the decor. Came for Sunday breakfast/brunch. My friend ordered off the menu while I tried their buffet. She ordered the corned beef hash with poached eggs and coffee. A couple minutes later the waitress came to say they don't have fresh pressed juice today. We said OK but we didn't order pressed juice. So then she asked us again what we ordered. Buffet was decent but nothing special. It didn't have an omelette station or a waffle station. The scrambled eggs were under done for my taste. The blueberry pancakes were good and so was the granola yogurt cups. The scones were the worst I ever had and I couldn't eat it. It was so dry you would think they were a month-old. When The corn beef hash and poached eggs came one poached egg was fine and the other was hard boiled so had to be sent back. Why the kitchen served it that way and why the waitress served it that way when it was obviously hard boiled is frustrating. And when we pointed it out to the waitress she acted like she didn't know what a poached egg was. Repeatedly we had to ask for coffee refills. Overall not at the level of other Hyatt regency dining locations.
author: Allison M.

description:
Terrible place! Came here on a week day at 6:30pm. It looked like a conference had been at the hotel. The bar was busy but only 2 bartenders were working. They moved slow and cold only pour one drink at a time. Management was also behind the bar but refused to help customers. 

Poorly run, poor planning of staff, and terrible drinks. Bar was a mess. On top of all that they were out of multiple items. So many other bars to go to.
author: Alan H.

description: Excellent service. Excellent food. Excellent ambience. There are 6 TVs to watch sports games and plenty of seats for many customers. They have a great wine selection and strong cocktails!
author: Lisa G.

description: Decent food, terrible service. Bartenders don't have a sound knowledge of beers on tap and waitress that we had was hard to track down and not very attentive.
author: Rick S.

description: Terrible service. The people working here don't care at all and overcharged me 3 times what my food was worth. They know nothing about the wines or what they are serving. They look at you like you are crazy when you try to order from the menu because they don't know what the items are themselves.
author: S M.

description:
The only eclipse to see is my bloated belly covering up the rising sun.  We're talking total eclipse, baby!

Eclipse Breakfast Buffet/ $28.95

During my business trip to San Francisco,  my stay at the Hyatt Regency included breakfast buffets at Eclipse Kitchen & Bar.  Located in the world's largest hotel lobby, Eclipse Kitchen & Bar boast seasonal, locally-sourced food on their menu.  This includes cage-free eggs, hormone free milk & naturally cured bacon.  Being in a hotel lobby, a high price tag is du rigueur, but at Las Vegas buffet level price of admission, let's see how Eclipse' breakfast buffet measures up.

Deli meat-
https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/eclipse-kitchen-and-bar-san-francisco-4?select=e2xO_Sqmmz0p3zs8ZnYbVQ
Being a highly enthusiastic carnivore, the deli meat were what I gravitated to the most.  The prosciutto was mouth-pleasingly tender & the Genoa salami unctuously salty.  But, the one I really piled on my plates every morning was the smoked salmon.  Sweet, oily & melt in your mouth, I was correct in not bringing fish oil on my trip, as I managed to pack away a pound of salmon to start my days every morning.  

Smoked salmon-
https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/eclipse-kitchen-and-bar-san-francisco-4?select=M3DdrAFLnRTv2S7xVD0TFw

Another great dish on the buffet line was the baked corned beef hash.  I don't partake of corned beef that much, so this was quite a treat.  The crumbs on top provided a wonderful crunch with each bite of oily corned beef.
Baked corned beef hash-
https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/eclipse-kitchen-and-bar-san-francisco-4?select=7T0Lk9fmgbzv7MYIE5psLg

Eggs benedict-
https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/eclipse-kitchen-and-bar-san-francisco-4?select=c16uwjhhtxqDLgBmq_oMjQ
Can't be considered a fancy breakfast place w/o eggs benedict!  These more than held their own, as the eggs were cooked correctly.  

The usual breakfast buffet suspects were well represented.  Steel cut oatmeal, an endless mound of naturally cured bacon, scrambled eggs, huevos rancheros & pastries of various ilk.  Dessert options had fresh, seasonal fruit & parfaits.  Coffee and//or orange juice are included with the buffet.  I simply chose seltzer water w/ lime, as OJ gives me GI problems.

Service was good.  The buffet was constantly stocked with food, and our plates were cleared in a timely manner.  Plenty of seating, which I usually chose by the food.  Hey, easy access!

The Eclipse Kitchen & Bar is located in the lobby of the Hyatt Regency Embarcadero.

While I enjoyed the food & service at Eclipse Kitchen & Bar's breakfast buffet, at almost $30 before tax & tip, I wanted more.  Granted, it's in a swanky hotel, but I'd have expectations for  more swanky eats for the pricepoint.  I'm glad it was included with my stay, as I didn't go hungry.  In fact, I probably ate enough calories for 3 people after each meal.
author: Rodney S.

description:
Service was outright terrible. Asked the bar tender if they were doing table service and was told yes. Two tables sat 5 minutes after us and we were the third table addressed by the waiter. When he finally took our order, he stopped and took the order for a table of 6 on the way back. He was 10 feet from the service counter to submit our drinks before taking theirs. We got there before them but because he waited, our drinks were delayed until after their items. BS! He came back 30 minutes after delivering our drinks to ask if we wanted anything and at that point, we wanted the check. Again, third party given our check. 

Needless to say, he got a $0.25 tip so he knew we left something but nothing else. 

Horrible. Horrible. Horrible experience.
author: Kevin K.

description:
A solid 3.5 stars for happy hour at Eclipse Kitchen & Bar.  Located inside the Hyatt Regency at Embarcadero, Eclipse certainly has the potential to be a popular spot for happy hours for local Fidi workers as well as hotel guests and tourists.  The lobby level has been renovated with modern, posh decor and an inviting ambiance.  Eclipse is located on this level and you cannot miss it.  The bar stands out as the main visual attraction, surrounded by different unique seating arrangements for any sized party.  They have community tables in the back, intimate booth seating on the sides with private overhangs, open lounge seating as well as tables for two with comfy sofa seats fit for a queen.  If any of those do not suit you, there is ample space at the bar.      

Friend and I met up for happy hour shortly after 5pm on a weekday.  We choose to sit at one of the intimate booths with plenty of table space for us to order several dishes.  Our servers were friendly and quickly came to greet us and take drink orders. The menu has a good selection of appetizers, salads, burger/sandwiches, entrees, bar snacks and desserts - enough variety but not overwhelming.  Their cocktail menu is unique and there is also a good wine list.  Although the happy hour menu isn't extensive, their appetizers which are not listed on special pricing are still reasonably priced, especially comparing to other downtown SF happy hour menus.  They also have charcuterie and cheese plates, which are always a hit for happy hour especially with wine pairings. 

We ordered several dishes, among those were definitely more hits than misses.  Every dish had nice presentation and portions were sufficient for sharing.
- Shoestring Truffle Fries ($8): I love shoestring fries and these did not disappoint.  The portion was a huge heaping serving. They were perfectly fried without being greasy or soggy.  There was enough truffle flavor but we could have used a little more. 
- Potstickers ($12):  5 chicken and veggie potstickers came abed a sweet/savory soy sauce.  They were cooked just right with a crispy exterior.  Flavor and texture were on point. 
- Classic Ensenda Fish Tacos ($18): The portion came with two decently sized tacos and sides of sour cream and chili.  The battered fish pieces were ample and had a mild spicy kick.  I thought the slaw wasn't as fresh as it could have been as the cabbage was a bit wilted, making it a little stringy and difficult to eat.  Nice touch with the slice of avo on top. 
- Giant Baked Meatball ($14): I was pleasantly surprised to hear that it was made with lamb meat, so had to try.  The meatball was indeed giant, accompanied with two grilled pieces of garlicy sourdough.  A spicy tomato sauce accompanied the meatball for added flavor.  Conceptually a wonderful dish, but the meatball itself was just way to salty for our palettes.  
- Cocktails ($15 each): I tried the Castro (virgin) and friend had the Mission.  Cute concept of having cocktails named after different neighborhoods in SF.  I thought the drink was well balanced even though I had a nonalcoholic one.  However, lacking was the presentation.  They were served in regular glasses (the same we had for our waters) without any type of garnishes.  I'd expect a little more pizazz for a $15 drink.  

I also noticed that the happy hour times at Eclipse were 3:00-5:30pm.  I'd suggest having a later window for happy hour to draw in more foot traffic.  With so many bars/restaurants in FiDi, there has to be something enticing to get the patrons to come by.  It would be nice to have more happy hour drink specials as well.  Overall, a pleasant experience at Eclipse.  I wouldn't mind going back to try a few other dishes and dessert.  The ambiance is welcoming and comfortable.  Compared to a bar, you don't have to yell over other conversations and loud music.  By the time we left around 7pm, there was a good amount of people who came for an after work drink and bite to eat.  Most of the seating was occupied as was the bar area.  Not the rowdy, young crowd but more catering to a sophisticated and mature clientele.  The location is right above the Embarcadero Bart/Muni station so it is very convenient for those taking public transportation.
author: Liv A.

description: I had the pleasure of eating breakfast at this awesome restaurant located within the Hyatt in San Francisco. Staff were very attentive, asked how we were and ensured that we didn't need anything. The prices seem high but for the area it is to be expected not to mention the food was fresh, restaurant was clean which made the price worth it!
author: Kie A.

description:
Meh. Pretty cool scene for a hotel bar.

I thought this bar used to be in another location of the hotel - but during the remodel, I guess it moved?

Good selection of beers on tap. A rotating happy hour food menu. That's good.

The only thing I wish was that service might've been a little faster. I understand pacing between courses, but between order, first drink, checking in, things were pretty spaced out. Yes, it was mildly busy... but customer service?

Booths are pretty fun. That's probably what drew us there.

Not the cheapest in town. $19 something for a beer and Jack & coke. But not highway robbery either.
author: Kristin Leigh M.

description: As hotel bar and grills go, this place is top notch. The ambience leaves a little something to be desired, as it sits right in the middle of the hotel lobby with a few strange seating options, but the food and service are reliably good. Most of the staff are quite friendly, although attentiveness can drop if it's crowded. The burger here is one of the best in the city: with extra sharp white cheddar and bread and butter pickles, it offers a lot of flavor. I wouldn't go out of my way for Eclipse, but it's really a solid choice if you happen to be around.
author: Andrew D.

description: Stayed at the Hyatt and came down to the bar a few times and had excellent service and great drinks. Staff was friendly and prompt. Would come again.
author: Mark P.

description: Great service. Staying at this hotel and enjoyed a wonderful NY Steak dinner. Friendly service.
author: Patrick C.

description:
Looooove the decor. There are giant hanging Christmas lights which beautifies the place. During Christmas, they host a snow fall event which is pretty neat for those of us who haven't seen snow (SAD RIGHT?). It's a very chill environment. I definitely like the couches they have for customers to lounge in. Very comfortable and quiet.

Came here for happy hour. Ordered chicken wings $14 and garlic fries $6. Our waiter was telling us that a friend of his counted about 64 fries. I would count, but I lost track after 3 because at that point, I was just shoveling up fries. The fries were good but not garlicky enough. There were 3 whole chicken wings that came with barbecue sauce. Fried well but the flavor was lacking.

Great service, beautiful place to be, comfortable, but when it comes to food, I've had better elsewhere at a better price. Even with Osha Thai, they had expensive small portion wings but they were delicious as hell!
author: Benita M.

description:
Stayed at the Hyatt on Mother's Day, with breakfast as part of the deal. Wasn't sure if I should do it after reading some reviews of the breakfast, but am glad I did!

First thing I've got to commend is the length. It's from 6-12!

You can be the world's laziest bastard and still feast here; a real weekend treat.

Seating was in various, scattered areas around the bar area, from cute little nooks for 2 to a large open area on the edge of the lobby.

I love to read papers, and browse books,, which this place does in spades. The NYT, SF Chronicle and WSJ which is A-OK and a smattering of other books to peruse.

There is the option to order off menu or to order the buffet, which we did.

Nice choice of seasonal fruit with a single yoghurt cup and muesli as well as oats makes for a nice beginning. There's a cold platter section with cold meats, including prosciutto, salmon and trimmings. 

With the hot there were really decent eggs benedict, scrambled eggs, sliced potatos, excellent bacon and some of the better sausages I've had outside the UK.

They also had a little unusual selection of dishes. There was a small, cute dim sum selection, a Dutch apple pie, a cool little quiche and some perfect little fruit crepes.

Juice was on demand and I only saw one offered. Coffee was decent and refilled quickly.

There were also a decent selection of bagels, breads and very good ( albeit it cold ) croissants.

The biggest plus is sitting and enjoying then biggest hotel lobby in the world, scene of the film High Anxiety (7/10)

Waiting here for a visitor, we sat for 2 hours, without beingg bothered and feeling very comfortable.

For an external visitor I think it was $28 each plus tax plus tip coming to $75 which could be a bit steep but at $50 all inclusive wasn't too bad.
author: Pantera W.

description:
The service is great, the food is great, and the atmosphere is great. I like what they've done with the place, having frequented the Hyatt for its food and drink for the past ten years. 

I am hesitant to praise any further because of how much they've hiked the prices since revamping the bar and lounge areas. One might argue, reasonably I might add, that it serves the sleeker environment to charge more for what they've got. However, I have never once paid $6 for a cup of black coffee -- not anywhere, not ever. Not New York, LA, country clubs, outer space -- you get my point. 

$17+ cocktails are pricey but not unforeseen in San Francisco. $19 breakfast items are not unheard of at exceptional hotels. But a $6 cup of coffee? Come on. That's absurd, and we're knowingly suckers paying for it. 

My patronage here has obviously receded over the years, and nowadays it's close to nothing. Over time I had gotten well acquainted with the staff, and they're why I would continue coming back. The people make the place. But these prices have been hiked to a point that dining here is too exclusive. Whomever conceived $6 coffees should surely think so. In summary, I am saddened. 

I will return, someday, of course. Just need to swing by the bank first to take out a loan.
author: J.I. B.

description:
Two years later I still feel the same about Eclipse

Chicken wings were seasoned well but difficult to eat 
Mac & cheese was underseasoned, needed more cheese and too greasy 

My friends loved their burgers and were surprised at how good it really was so take that for what its worth 

Overall Thoughts

For a hotel restaurant it certainly does the job to satisfy your cravings but for the price you might have some doubts if its worth it
author: Eddie W.

description:
My hotel accommodation included breakfast for each day. So I was fortunate enough to have eaten breakfast here for 5 straight days. Food selection is extensive. Quality and taste is decent. The staff were always so kind and welcoming. They definitely are the reason why I gave them four stars. Tip them well!

The hotel bar is well designed and has TVs tuned in to different sports and news channels. I love their wine selection especially the President which is a red blend.
author: Dan P.

description:
We had a Bad experience at the Eclipse 
The food is okay , the customer service is horrible . The servers have an attitude like they don't want to be their .
One server dropped a plate of food and it almost got on one of us and then we had to listen to her arguing with someone on who should have to clean it up. 
Then when we got up and left our server (young short Hispanic girl with 2 pony tails) chased us down and asked us why we gave her a small tip ( which we didn't) and then she rolled her eyes and gave a bitch looking stare, even if you get a small tip how do you have the heart or the nerves to call someone out on that , maybe they can't afford to give a big tip and they gave all they can afford. 
The manager is a good guy,  he was working harder than his workers where,  it's a shame he is stuck with these low lifes
author: Gary E.

description:
I find it extraordinarily insulting and upsetting when restaurants with a captured audience (IE in a hotel) feel that they do not have to try because of that. See my review for Bacchus Wine Bar for a similar experience.

We decided to head to the Eclipse restaurant because it was convenient and we were in need of a Bloody Mary, stat. We were seated quickly and our drink orders were taken in about five minutes of seating. Our water glasses were removed and we had to ask for water to be returned. After our drinks came we then sat for another ten minutes watching about 5 waiters wander around clearing tables, offering juice, and generally ignoring us. We had our menus turned upside down to indicate (shouldn't have had to this) that we were ready to order and still were ignored. Our waitress finally appeared from the back and took our order. I was already ticked off from the wait.

I think part of the confusion can be associated with the breakfast buffet as many of the people in the restaurant seemed to take advantage of that (looked super tasty but too pricy for my taste since I wanted a cocktail), yet you would think even in that case when servers have less to do they would be more attentive.

I got the corned beef hash with a 'spicy Bloody Mary sauce' and poached eggs (I asked for medium on the eggs). My husband got the two eggs (over easy) with bacon and toast. When our food came out my eggs were decidedly not medium and his were almost cooked through. The sauce with my hash was basically hugely chunked tomatoes from a can and no spice at all. I asked for ketchup. My hash was greasy (although it is corned beef...). Husbands bacon was perfectly crisp and thick and his sourdough toast was cold. 

Overall we had a mediocre experience. They did comp two of our bloody Mary's for our patience which I appreciated, but would have preferred good service in the first place. This effort did bump them from two stars to three (my husband suspects they saw me taking pictures of the food). I am coming down more and more on ALWAYS venturing out of hotels when getting food, because clearly they don't seem to care.
author: Heather L.

description:
Brunch with Santa is back for 2016!!!****** 

After a year hiatus, breakfast with Santa is back and the menu is better than ever! It's an annual tradition for us (all you can eat brunch in an amazingly decorated space? Yes please) and we were so happy the Santa Brunch came back this year.  

Smoked salmon, quiche, cookies for the kids, waffles,  pancakes, cheeses, woah I could go on.... it's such a yummy splurge! 

Afterwards go for a walk along the water or to the park overlooking the ferry building. A very popular play structure is a few yards away.  

And take BART or Muni.  Fun and kids loved taking a Sunday adventure.
author: Sf Momm Y.

description: Went for "happy hour" or bait and switch. Worst happy hour ever. $1 off $16 drinks. I don't think so. Not coming back here.
author: Kai T.

description:
A group of us decided to come for a happy hour after work, and were sorely disappointed by the lack of service. Despite our group being the only customers when we sat down, our drinks took at least 20 minutes to arrive, and the wait time on the appetizers wasn't any better. Nobody came in to check on us after we got our food and drinks, and we had to flag down a waiter to ask for water, which took yet another 10-15 minutes to arrive.

Drinks and food were decent for a hotel restaurant/bar, but the quality of the service left a bad taste.
author: Emily Z.

description:
Come here for the prison food! No joke, in conjunction with the Hyatt Regency's "Alcatraz: Life on the Rock" exhibit, Eclipse is serving an updated interpretation of the prison's menu from now until October. http://bit.ly/18N5OUT

Did you know that Alcatraz actually prided itself on serving inmates relatively healthy/tasty food from locally sourced ingredients? If that's not farm-to-table, don't know what is! Old menus were examined and re-created on tin trays to commemorate the occasion... We're talking comfort food at its best too: Stuffed cabbage, mashed potatoes, meatloaf, roasted zucchini squash, spaghetti (for Al Capone, of course!), short ribs and mac 'n' cheese! This lucky lady right here didn't have to break any laws or don an orange jumpsuit to try the food, either! Nope, I was simply invited to attend a special unveiling. Intriguing, yes?

Obviously it's a novelty menu, paying homage to a life that likely none of us ever experienced (or will have to). Even if you got sent "up the river" these days, your meals would likely be serviced by Aramark or whatever large food service company was lucky enough to land a government contract. From what we were told, prisoners at Alcatraz helped prepare the food and were allowed to go back for seconds, assuming they finished everything on the tray. 

When you've wiped that plate clean, go explore the lobby atrium! There's a replica jail cell, complete with bars on the wall. Makes for an excellent profile pic. And no, you cannot sleep in here at a discounted price (apparently there have been some inquiries at the hotel proper). Read all about life as an Alcatraz inmate OR simply book a ticket to visit the island proper. After all, orange is the new black, right?
author: Abby S.

description:
Came here for after dinner drinks. Had never been to this Hyatt, and I heard banghra music as we went up 2 flights on the escalator. They were having a Yoga convention, as we saw from the signs. As we approached the restaurant/lounge, I was amazed by all the twinkling lights hanging above. Felt like a little kid seeing Christmas lights for the first time.

We sat in a comfy couch, although the ones across from each other are quite far, so not really able to have a decent conversation from facing so far apart. A waitress came shortly and took our wine orders. We received our glasses (and water since we were so thirsty!) and bill quickly after. I had a glass of rose, that was bit drier for my taste, but still enjoyed it. Definitley like the ambience of this lounge, and service was great.
author: Denise L.

description: The new Eclipse kitchen and bar is awesome. A recent multi million Dollar renovation has transformed the space. Beers on tap, creative cocktails,  outstanding pupu's make Eclipse kitchen and bar a new hot spot in the financial district.  Check it out
author: David L.

description: Quick service, attentive managers, delish appetizers. Go and check this place out, great place to unwind after a long day at work. Don't forget to get Castro street cocktail, refreshing .
author: Ria P.

description:
Surprisingly good food in this hotel restaurant/bar, and reasonably priced considering the quality. The butter lettuce salad and mushrooms with polenta were both delightful as an afternoon snack. Happy hour goes from 4:30-6:30 and includes $5 wells as well as a rotating $4 beer. If you're staying at the Hyatt and are hungry, try this place out. 

Late night the staff gets a bit less impressive. Our waitress double billed us for a drink, and misrepresented what was actually in a drink. When the menu says strawberry purée without the word FRESH it means they're using that craptastic daiquiri mix. Don't order it! She did correct the 'error' on the bill, but it took a while.
author: Kaia V.

description: Standard hotel restaurant.  Food is ok.  What I do like about it is that it's open relatively late for San Fran and the space is nice.  It's in the atrium of the Hyatt Regency.  For breakfast it's a bit hectic, but for dinner and snacks it's peaceful.
author: Stuart B.

description:
Really great free bread that they serve at the beginning.
And really pretty view of the Hyatt lights and Christmas decorations during winter.

But such overpriced boring food and ... just why does this place exist? I guess it's healthy because the food is so plain. 

Just don't come. Trust the Yelp reviews. Tourist trap.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Your standard hotel bar and restaurant.

I had breakfast here the first morning at the hotel. I opted for the breakfast buffet - which was pretty good as breakfast buffets go - although very expensive. I had their corned beef hash, which appeared to made from scratch and with real shredded corned beef. I also tried a link of sausage, some bacon, breakfast potatoes, and scrambled eggs, plus a bit of smoked salmon and a glass of pink grapefruit juice. Everything was reasonably hot and tasty.

The other times in here were in the evening - a couple of times for a bite to eat and/or drinks. I tried their Burger - I forget what came on it, it was served with some crisp, tasty sweet potato fries and a side of crisp slices of dill pickle. Overall, a good burger . Another evening I got an order of their garlic fries - topped with fresh garlic sauce with herbs in it - very fragrant and pungent - yet the fries still retained that wonderful crispness and texture.

They serve a local craft beer here - "Big Daddy IPA" (Speakeasy Ales & Lagers), which is served in bottles. A nice IPA - somewhat on the light side from a hops perspective, but other than that, nicely balanced in terms of citrus and pine notes.

They also make a good dirty vodka martini here, although I was disappointed there was no option for blue cheese or gorgonzola stuffed olives (all they offer are standard pimento stuffed olives).

Service was good. It can get a bit crazy in here when the bar and lounge area gets packed in the evening - it might take them a few minutes to get your drink to you...
author: Neal E.

description: We had a business lunch here to discuss our upcoming meeting and it was surprisingly good!  I enjoyed the eggs benedict and herbal tea and was very happy with my choices.  Nice open atmosphere in the hotel lobby, good food and good service too.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
The Eclipse Restaurant at the Hyatt Regency is good to keep in mind for the right occasion. I met a good friend here because she swears by it for lunch. I understand why, as I had a deliciously well-prepared piece of grilled salmon on a bed of mixed greens and lentils. At $19, it's a business meal price, and not just a place to head from the office for a bite. For business meals, this is a pretty and quiet space. The open atrium provides a bit of atmosphere and the tables are well spaced, allowing for easy conversation. The service was timely and pleasant. 

Lunch pricing:
The starters are $8 - $15
Lunch salads are $14 - $18
Sandwiches and fish tacos $15 - $16
Entrees are $14 - $19

If you want some of the same experience, but care to dine elsewhere, the adjacent Eclipse Lounge is decent place to have a drink. Not a destination, but a hotel-convenient spot for a drink. Wines start at $9. The Franciscan chardonnay is a good choice. I like the Estancia pinot noir as well.
author: Ted R.

description: I've been meaning to review this for a while--have had great experiences here on several occasions. The service is excellent, great drinks, apps etc. Brad-- in particular-- was awesome. I also really enjoyed staying at the Hyatt on New Year's eve and drinking at Eclipse. Great Breakfast there new year's day too!
author: Michael C.

description: Had a very nice late lunch a couple days ago. I ordered Crab Louis, husband Beef Brisket Sandwich. Mine was a feast for the eye as much as the palate! Attaching a pic, it was so pretty. Unfortunately,  hubby's sandwich wasn't up to par for someone who's enjoyed that dish in Texas. But the french fries were delicious! Service was pretty good, considering they were pretty thinly dispersed.
author: Mara B.

description:
Service and food is on point. I had lunch and evening drinks at Eclipse. For lunch I had a simple but delicious arugula salad and Carlos B. was friendly and professional. The lounge waiter in the evening was also very helpful while we enjoyed our cocktails and side of fries. 

I would definitely revisit this place. They even have happy hour on Sundays when other establishments are closed. Enjoy!
author: Mel B.

description: Decent food. Atmosphere is nice for breakfast. Although service was terrible and essentially ruined a nice breakfast. Many other customers around were frustrated as well. Food deserves 3 stars, service 1. Took about 15 minutes to get drinks served simply to the table. Avoid if you can.
author: Matt M.

description: We went there on Christmas eve and just in time to see the snow fall at 4pm... but hardly noticeable snow flakes.. more like no snow fall. Very disappointed, but their light decoration is beautiful~ 300,000 lights i heard... having a glass of wine at eclipse lounge while enjoying the xmas carol+amazing light decoration was perfect!
author: Suzy H.

description: Very disappointed, we didn't do Santa's breakfast last year because of the remodel but probably won't do it again. The new restaurant lacks ambiance and the feeling from the initial sit down is to get you out as quick as possible. Waitress drops tab on table after pouring first cup of coffee. The staff need to have a talking with and understand this is a experience and not a way of life.
author: Martin B.

description: Interesting food choices and environment in the Hyatt Embarcadero lobby. The food was pretty good, the service good, and a little pricey. The restaurant is not well organized nor the seating appropriate for dining.
author: Jim T.

description: Sat at the bar for a beer on Sunday at about 3PM. They were out of both brands of draft beer I ordered. Well, I don't know if they were actually out or if they were just too lazy to change the kegs. In general, service was just uninterested and the bartenders were more interested in talking amongst themselves and only showed the absolute minimal interest in the customer. I'm guessing they're union workers.
author: Scott W.

description: Though the hotel was beautiful and the food was good, the service at the kitchen was terrible. We waited for 20 min before they came to ask us for our order. Prior to that we attempted to order at the bar with no success. The waiters didn't seem to be communicating at all. Refills on drinks were impossible to obtain and and a simple request for ketchup seemed to never come. Overall the hotel with their decorations and food were great but the service was terrible. Definitely won't be eating here again.
author: Itzia E.

description: Such gorgeous decor and I only have just discovered such place. Warning, the place is a bit chilly so additional clothing is advised. There were plenty of seating for happy hour. However, their happy hour appetizers were lacking. There wasn't anything filling that interested me. The fries were yummy but still. Please change your menu to better appetizers! The signature cocktails were a tad expensive but wished they had a few more fruitier cocktails. :)
author: Ann L.

description:
My wife and I had a long drive, checked in and went to the "restaurant" for dinner.  The restaurant was basically tables in a bar.  Loud music, huge TVs, no ambiance.  Well we were too tired to go out so we ordered from the menu.  I ordered the buttermilk fried chicken wings.  There were 3 and they were very greasy, grease was pooled at the bottom, cooked well, lacking flavor.  My wife ordered the beer cheese spread with grilled bread, the bread was greasy and the chews was ok.  We each ordered a drink and a desert.  I had the shortcake biscuit and strawberries.  The biscuit could not even be cut with a fork and knife, the strawberries were diced and I don't think they used more than 2 strawberries either.  My wife had the buttermilk cheesecake, she said it lacked any flavor.

The total bill was $70!  Now I know that SF is an expensive city but the cost of crappy bar food was ridiculous.  Order takeout, anything but eating at the Eclipse Restaurant!
author: Jack D.

description:
Super strong martini and somewhat large. Pretty much straight shot of Vodka. Decided to not have a second. 

-3 olives
author: Gregory P.

description:
Great view of the impressive Hyatt atrium and hanging lights.

The restaurant is open to midnight, but they stop serving food at 11pm.
You can get drinks and coffee till midnight. 
I have had a few late night meetings here.

The food in the evening is average, the service is ok.

They could do so much more with this place given the amazing atrium.
author: David T.

description: As good as it gets! Really impressed with the creative cocktail selection. The redesigned space is very inspiring.
author: Josh R.

description: My family and I recently stayed at the Hyatt for a couple days. Our stay was nice, the hotels lobby is beautiful so we decided to try the Eclipse, which is right in the center. First I was carded after ordering my drink, the waitress looked at my ID and insisted it wasn't me which I took as a compliment at first until she had the manager come take a double check. He apologized for the inconvenience but I was still turned off, we had one drink and left. My mom wanted to try breakfast there for our last day before we left so she made reservations. It was 10am and we were right on time, told the guy in the front who I'm guessing was the host that we had reservations. He was soooo stuck up and rude it wasn't even funny, he was like "it would help if you gave me your name and time for your reservation." Dude how many people really have reservations this damn early in the morning?!! He was a jack ass who obviously hates his life and job as if that's our problem. The food and drinks are very good but the staff could use some work, it's not hard to be polite to customers who are paying a lot to be here.
author: Britany B.

description: Came here for a drink in the evening and a weeknight and their wine selection is out of this world. Love seeing the prisoner wine available by glass. And their burger is delicious!!! Also our server was really down to earth and a total sweetheart. This is going to be a favorite spot for future.
author: Jasmine G.

description:
I was here for holiday drinks with Boyfriend and a couple of our coworkers after our staff holiday party. This lounge/restaurant is located in the Hyatt Regency hotel lobby and, since it was the holidays, the millions of twinkly string lights had the place glowing softly. It was absolutely beautiful (this is one of my favorite places to see during the holiday season because of those lights).

I had ordered their alcoholic apple cider (also a holiday staple and I believe only part of their holiday menu). It's a warm drink in a cute, fluted mug with a cinnamon stick floating around inside and liberally splashed with whiskey.

It was amazing. The warm drink was just what I needed to keep me toasty from the winter chill outside. My coworkers (Boyfriend, too!) thought that the drink was sweet, but not overly so because the whiskey cut the cider just right. And with the floating cinnamon stick adding just that right touch of holiday spice kick, I was enjoying myself immensely. My only complaint would be the price -- it was pretty much $10 to get this cocktail (though compared to most San Francisco touristy prices, I guess it really isn't THAT bad).

We seated ourselves at one of those weird booth-table things with the raised bar chair/stools for seating. Sadly, every single one of our chairs were too high for the table height (since we were at the part that dipped shorter in the middle), but we just sat back a bit and enjoyed ourselves.

Staff never insisted that we take a menu or seemed to want to hurry us along after we had finished our round of drinks and were just relaxing and chatting. They simply left us be after we turned down food and we were able to sit down, relax and just chitchat at our leisure without any disapproving servers staring at us in order to silently hurry us along. I would come back for more drinks (alas, if only they had the holiday drink menu available all year long...)!
author: Anna W.

description: Visited the Eclipse Restaurant & Bar with a few friends after work and WOW, I was blown away. It looks like the restaurant went under a huge renovation -- brand new seating and decor. My expectations were exceeded by the delicious food, craft cocktail choices, and awesome atmosphere. I would recommend ordering the brussel sprouts, flat breads, and truffle fries! Highly recommended, I will definitely be back!
author: Kelly G.

description: What a fantastic experience at Eclipse Kitchen & Bar. I was impressed with the selection of appetizers and creative beverage menu. Additionally, the seating was very comfortable as our party was able to have a great view of the impressive atrium. This hotel has tranformed over the years and looks fantastic. I will return to this bar when in the area as it has a terrific vibe and positive energy.
author: John H.

description:
Came here for DAT with coworkers. I was dazzled by the lights. The venue is lovely, housed in a large atrium within the Hyatt. Lights just seem to rain down on you in an elegant and airy space.

But the food didn't really match the beauty of its setting. First course was a chicken tortilla soup, which had pretty good depth of flavor to it. A slight hint of a kick from the spices and a nice crunch from the tortilla strips. Second course---the fish tacos---was where disappointment hit. While I appreciate the choice of corn tortillas and slaw-like lettuce, the fish was not seasoned at all. AT ALL! So the entire dish was bland and flavorless. The beans on the side reminded me of something they dished up back in elementary school. Again, however, the presentation was nice... but I'd rather eat something tasty and not as pretty to look at.

The bread did come with roasted garlic olive oil, which I thought was a nice touch. But it wasn't enough to save that meal.
author: J J.

description: Just finished breakfast with my husband and our toddler at the Eclipse restaurant at the Hyatt. Ruben was our waiter and he was fantastic!! In fact the whole staff was!! They brought us free orange juice for the baby and everything else we asked for and then some. We will definitely be back next time we are in SF :)
author: Jessica Camy W.

description:
I am in the process of staying here for 2 weeks. Even though the stay here is average to nice, this isn't about the hotel as much as it is about the eclipse bar and restaurant. In my opinion the food selection is somewhat dull and average. The breakfast is decent but you better get it with the room deal because it isn't worth the price if I had to pay up front.

Here is where the bar falls apart. I've seen on two occasions where others have ordered beers and the server, would grab a filled glass out of the wine fridge or from under the taps and pour the beer into another glass to present a good head and fresh poured beer. Now I could blame the server if it was the same one. Instead it was a different one each time. Now I blame management 

I would recommend going somewhere else personally or watch them like a hawk because if they cut corners on a fresh beer then where does the line they cross stop.
author: Ty G.

description: WOW! This place is unreal. The new renovations are absolutely perfect- so modern and inviting. I loved having the craft cocktails and tasty apps here with my friends after work- perfect spot in the financial district. Highly recommend.
author: Rachel S.

description:
Drinks - great!
service - something to be desired.....  It was a super crowded happy hours and they appeared to be way understaffed.  Our server was kind enough, but she was so slow.  The kind of slow where you want to order your second drink as soon as you get your first one because it will take that long to get a drink.

Hot tip: It's next to their front desk which is -not- on ground level.

Hot tip: The front desk was super nice and broke a twenty for me.
author: Chloe M.

description:
4 stars for food, but probably mostly on the amazing service by our waitress.

Located inside the huge & beautiful lobby of the Hyatt. The night we came in there was a sign by the front that said "Please seat yourself", not sure if they do this all the time or not. I had a friend waiting for me who was able to get a seat for us near the bar. The pace looked really busy, but I think that's partly due to the convention or event they were having in their conference area downstairs.

It's December so the lobby was decorated for Christmas with a giant tree and a winter village (including the GG Bridge) around the fountain & sculpture.

So we were set on getting a salad, but we wanted some kind of protein on the side (chicken, beef, etc) We asked about their chicken & beef. The waitress was so nice & helpful, she actually went to the back to check on the seasoning on the meats. She came back and told us exactly what was in their marinades. Then we asked if they can just do plain grilled chicken just salt & pepper no spices. She went back again and came back with a "yes".

The one thing I have to say is that our wait was quite long, for "custom" food here. There were a couple tables around us who had their food out faster than ours. And we only had salads with grilled chicken. Really? I don't think it should take that long... Especially seeing that the other two tables had far more food than we ordered.

Good experience. Good food. The waitress who helped us was wonderful!
author: Joel R.

description: In my half-century life I've ordered a number of eggs Benedict, but this is by far the most exquisite mouthful of breakfast joy I've partaken of. The crab cakes & spinach with an outrageous sauce & perfect eggs made it divine. It was served with quinoa, ripe raspberry and perfectly seasoned & cooked potatoes. My mouth & tummy are very happy. This & coffee came to $25.
author: Lisa S.

description: Cool restaurant, awesome food, great bar...check it out.  Our very picky daughter claims the Clam Chowder in the Bread Bowl is by far THE BEST anywhere!  I recommend the Fried Chicken Thighs with Mac & Cheese ~ Yum.  The portions are hearty - a fun place to go with friends and family.  On a scale of 1-5, I give it a 10. Cheers.
author: Starla B.

description: Decent-to-good food, but subpar service and pretty high prices. Our waitress tonight initially was planning to memorize our order, but changed her mind halfway through and used one of the napkins on our table to write it down. Not very professional at all.
author: Michael C.

description: I went to Eclipse Monday evening for cocktails and ended up staying for over two hours! It has a great vibe and I love all of the little details everywhere. First, I got the "22 year old CEO" cocktail which was delish and refreshing. I remembered a cocktail (honey rye) I used to get before they renovated and after describing it to the manager, she knew exactly what it was and made it herself for me! We had a few apps and while everything was tasty, I could eat their house made kettle chips all day. Pleasant service, great drinks/eats and chill environment - what more could you want?!
author: Kelly L.

description:
Most hotel lobbies are only good for checking in.  The lobby of the Hyatt Regency San Francisco is worth checking out.  We came in to see the magnificent lobby, but stayed to enjoy a beverage in the Eclipse lounge and ride in the retro glass elevators.

Our jaws dropped as we stepped into the 7 million cubic foot atrium lobby, considered by the Guinness Book as the world's largest.  On the lobby floor, Charles Perry's 40-foot tall anodized aluminum sculpture entitled "Eclipse" hovers over a square-sided fountain, where thin sheets of water flow over its vanishing edges.  Overhead, a cascade of over 300,000 white lights rain down from above.

Fortunately, our visit coincided with the 4:30 to 6:30 daily happy hour in the Eclipse lounge, where my domestic lager only set me back $4.  After a long day of sight-seeing, we appreciated the posh couches and soft sleek chairs, spaced far enough apart so that our conversations could remain low-volume and private.

For a little high anxiety after happy hour, we rode the iconic glass elevators to the top of the atrium.  We rose smoothly at 500 feet per minute in the illuminated capsules trimmed in polished brass.  Although the ride was free, it is not recommended for the acrophobic.

The Hyatt Regency deserves three stars for its record-setting and awe-inspiring atrium lobby, comfortable lounge and daily happy hour specials, and exciting elevator rides.  The festive Christmas decorations during the holidays warrant a fourth star, and are another reason this hotel lobby is worth checking out.
author: Joe R.

description:
I must preface this review by saying that I know it's long.  Please bear with me as I have provided detail, especially in the end section about why this place was bad, in order to help provide clarity and to demonstrate with specificity the bases for my review and justification for being able to rely on it.  

We just went here yesterday evening, 14 Dec. 2013, after a day in the city and were exceedingly disappointed to say the least, making it a rather poor end to the day.  We have been visiting the Hyatt, and periodically getting food and drink here since I was a kid when the hotel was new but this is the first time in about 3-4 years that we had gotten any drinks or food here.

The lobby of the Hyatt is magnificent, unless you hate modern architecture.  It is huge, open, with wonderful angles, sloping sides, balconies, wonderful fountain, etc., making it, in terms of decor, feel and ambience, always a delight to visit.  It is thus a great place to have a lounge/bar or eatery.Thus, for ambience, the place is a sure-fire 5 stars all the way.

First, I must get out of the way the issue of prices: prices are high - $13 for a manhattan is high no matter the quality.  That, however, goes without saying given that it's in this hotel and in San Francisco.  With the ambience, the price could be, and has been, at least bearable and sometimes definitely worth it.

But not this time.

The food, meat loaf sliders and garlic fries were very good and enjoyable, but not outstanding.  They were hardly subtle or very memorable, but they were enjoyed by all and we would get them again.  They would be an easy 3 stars of of yelp's 5, possibly as high as 3.5, and worth the try in order to have something to eat whilst relaxing in this lovely space.

However, and this is a huge however, the drinks (at the aforementioned high prices), were beyond dreadful.  They were the worst cocktails, and for the kids, virgin cocktails we have EVER had ANYWHERE.  They were easily on par with, if not worse, than the "cocktail" I had some years ago at Rainforest Cafe, a horrid place which I hope never to enter again (see my review on that).  

I want to make clear that this evaluation can be trusted as my wife and I are serious cocktail drinkers and cocktail makers, and have been for years. We drink everything from serious old-fashioned drinks like Old Fashioneds, Martinis (by which I mean the only drink that I would ever call a Martini - gin and vermouth and, if you like, some form of bitters) or Manhattans to a wide range of "Tiki" drinks.  We know good quality and we know what goes into proper drinks.  We also appreciate good-quality cocktails.  That said, we are fairly forgiving and usually at least enjoy even less-than-stellar cocktails.  

Here, we had an Old Fashioned, a Manhattan, and for a daughter a virgin strawberry cooler-type drink.  All were absolutely horrid.  First, the Old Fashioned is bourbon/ rye, bitters, a little sugar/simple syrup (and if you like an orange slice and cherry), nothing more.  The Manhattan is bourbon/rye, vermouth, and bitters.  The menus described them properly, listing the above-mentioned ingredients and stating that they were with Maker's Mark bourbon.  The kid's drink was to be Sierra Mist with strawberry puree and maybe something else.  No way did the drinks we were actually served even remotely fit the descriptions.  The whisky drinks were pale, the colour of diluted Irish whiskey, which is much more pale than bourbon.  They were basically just sweet and tasted very slightly of a hint of bourbon, both the colour and the flavour making it obvious that they were both VERY, VERY HEAVILY watered down.  I asked to have mine remade and when it came back, it looked and tasted like the same drink with a bunch of Everclear (high-proof, raw, unaged grain alcohol) added.  It was simply more full than before, at least as pale if not more pale and now tasted only of raw, rough, harsh alcohol, with no sweetness, orange, or even bourbon flavour noticeable at all.  As bad as the first drink was, this was worse.  

Our daughter's drink was simply plain club soda with a little bit of strawberry something (syrup?  It did not seem like an actual puree), just enough to make it red and give the faintest hint of strawberry.  

Not one of us could finish the drinks.
author: Wulfstan C.

description:
The best hotel breakfast I've had. ($23.95)
Really good quality. Scrambled eggs are perfectly cooked, delicious corned beef hush, bacon is good, nice and light ricotta pancakes with real maple syrup, fruits are fresh and sweet. Varieties of cold cuts and cheeses. 
Outstanding service.
author: Natasha S.

description:
Came here for Dine About Town with a friend and was a little disappointed with the food.  Service was alright, a little slow but courteous.  The ambience is great though - the restaurant is an open area located right in the middle of the hotel's beautiful atrium.

Starters - spring salad and clam chowder.  I barely touched the salad - not very good - but my friend did like her clam chowder.

Main - fried chicken and salmon.  Fried chicken was tasty - a hint of curry in the batter makes it interesting.  Salmon was fine but nothing to write home about.

Dessert - Ghiradelli molten chocolate cake and banana bread pudding.  OK, now we're talking.  Both were pretty delicious and up to the level I was expecting.

Overall, the desserts and the nice atmosphere saved the day.  I think this would be a great place to have drinks for happy hour but I wouldn't go out of my way to come back here.
author: Nilar H.

description:
One of my staples when visiting San Fran and staying at the Hyatt is the Eclipse Restaurant. I'm always partial to the Chicken Tortilla soup and the sweet potato fries but I also like to mix it up a bit. I've had most of the menu items, and I can say that I enjoyed them all. From salads, to burgers, chicken and steak. 

The service is always very friendly and I recently spoke to one of the managers who is a big fan of craft beer which I was happy to hear. I hope to have an even bigger variety of beers to choose from during my next visit!
author: Stephen C.

description:
Originally commuted to SF just for One Market's Amanda Blake drink but the darn place was closed (Jan. 2) so we had to resort to another place for alcohol nearby. This place is located inside The Hyatt across the street, upstairs. 

This place is for those that want a quick drink fix however, service was pretty much nonexistent and the wait time felt forever and I am not just saying that because I am an impatient person. 

Lora ordered the bayberry, I ordered the mojito, and once Sophorn joined, she too had the bayberry. Although in the end Lora and I switched drinks, I enjoyed the bayberry but there was no hint of alcohol, just juice and rather sweet so if you like pineapples and/or a drink that literally has no alcohol then order the bayberry. 

The girls ordered Thai wings or something which came w/ a heaping amount of crispy wings and drummettes, it came w/ a side of cucumber slaw. I only had a few pieces of the slaw but none of the wings since they are fried and goes against my New Year's resolution. Woot woot for damn willpower. 

In the end- juice for fancy alcohol price however, time w/ the girls? Priceless.
author: Tram N.

description: Slooooooooow AF!!!! Sitting for 45 minutes. Had to walk around to find a server and had the runaround between employees of how to order some food. Seat yourself and then get ignored. Order drinks from the bar.
author: connie c.

description:
Conveniently located within walking distance from the ferry building, my fiance chose this spot to meet with some old college friends of his from England, as it was easy enough for all of us to find since it's situated in the Embarcadero. We were seated promptly, and our servers were nice, although we did have to flag them down a few times toward the end of our meal (plus, I'm pretty sure my wine had initially been forgotten about, and that took awhile...). 

Nonetheless, we enjoyed the food brought to us and they featured Drakes hefeweizen for a decent price, which our out-of-towners seemed to enjoy very much! I was happy to see that they featured a separate non-alcoholic cocktail drink menu, which was nice for the newly pregnant wife of one of our friends. Everyone loved their meal, and I certainly enjoyed my fried chicken with mac and cheese. However, I do think the mac and cheese could have had far less oily grease... maybe I'm just picky?

Mixed feelings, yes, but overall we had an enjoyable experience!
author: Courtney S.

description:
We've eaten here 25 or 30 times over the last few years as we live nearby and would frequently drop in for a quick bite of some decent food with warm friendly service.   Unfortunately, since the restaurant "re-opened", it has gone downhill and tonight's entree was literally inedible.  My salad came out without any dressing so I had to wait 5 or 10 minutes after I pointed it out to get some dressing.  My wife's tea didn't come until after we had finished our apps.  My fish dish--supposedly black cod-- tasted like it had been frozen, thawed, refrozen and then left out--basically mush.   My wife's pot stickers were quite tasty but her steak was mediocre and I'm not convinced it was really from Niman Ranch. 
My recommendation:  If you are staying in the hotel and really don't feel like walking across the street to have much better food and you don't mind having boring tasteless food in a nice setting, this place is for you.  Otherwise, do yourself a favor and eat elsewhere.
author: Ace E.

description:
I took my friend here for lunch.  Yes it's in the foyer area of the Hyatt and you can easily miss it if you weren't looking.  Restaurant is quiet so you can actually have a decent conversation here without shouting.  Service was attentive.  We didn't have to wave anyone down whenever we needed anything.

I ordered the angus burger - medium well and garlic fries.  The burger was cooked to perfection - not burnt and certainly not bloody red.  Garlic fries were yummy.  For dessert I had the blueberry parfait.  That contained candied pecans, custard, bits of lemon bundt cake.  Very yummy.

This is a nice place to take someone to lunch to.
author: Wendy H.

description: The god dam server that was taking our order was completely horrible. He was fucking horrible from the beginning. He was rushing us and being extremely rude. I ordered a Strauss burger and my girlfriend ordered the shrimp Salad. The part that was the fucking most infuriating was when we got our check. The bill was for a total of $76 and some cents which is fine. But I payed $50 dollars cash and the $26 was gonna go on the card. The fucking idiot was trying to keep the $50 cash for himself and changed my girlfriends card for the whole amount. The fact that my girlfriend had to check her bank account to confirm the fact that this piece of shit was trying to rip us off is complete bullshit. This guy definitely should not be in food service. Plus he didn't check on us at all during our dinner.
author: Serbando V.

description: What a shame.  They took a beautiful hotel atrium and turned it in to an "I don't know what." Traditionally for the past few years another family and ours have  gone out for Breakfast With Santa.  I gave it two stars because Santa was spectacular and the buffet was as expected...cold food but edible. Otherwise it was just sad and a mere shadow of its former self.   When We pay $600 for breakfast for 9 adults, two babies and two toddlers ( 20% tip automatically added for what I have no idea), I actually expect a tablecloth on the table.  We are not talking here about pretty tables, dinnerware and flatware.  I've been in fancier cafeterias.  Because I asked if the mimosas and bloody Mary's they had were included and told yes, I was amazed at the extra hundred dollar charge for alcohol.  The manager on duty offered no explanation except to tell me it was illegal to serve "free alcohol".  Well unless it's included I 'm thinking but what do I know and I wasn't up for a scene. And it was Christmas and a bottle of Cooks Champagne has probably gone up. So we paid the bill including the RIDICULOUS gratuity but I won't be back and I'll be sure to advise my friends here in SF to stay away.  Next year, I will make breakfast, use my Christmas plates and ask Santa to just come here.  Why did I not think of that before!
author: Peggy M.

description: Talk about hovering...these servers won the prize! Sharks, vultures, whatever you call them theyre ready to swoop in for anything: sugar wrapers, more coffee(at least 6 times from 6 different servers), katchep, hot sauce? Ive been going here for years and they always run the show the same way. One lady even stood by my table for half the meal! I obviously come here for the food...I really enjoy the breakfast buffet! Today they had corned beef hash, eggs, and french toast(see my photo). In conculsion...if you come here look out for the predatory serving tactics, but you will definately enjoy the brunch buffet!
author: Danielle M.

description: Love the new Eclipse Bar and Grill! This place is awesome. Newly renovated, cool vibe with a mix of both local and out of town guests. Drinks are good. Service is awesome. Can't wait to go back soon.
author: Morgan I.

description: I was staying at the Hyatt Regency, and decided to grab a drink at the hotel bar while I was waiting for a friend. The Eclipse Lounge has a small circular bar in the middle of it (how clever), with maybe 15 seats, and two bartenders slinging drinks. When I arrived around 9pm, most of the bar seats were taken, but it wasn't busy. I stood within clear eye sight of both bartenders and was ignored for 10 minutes before I decided to walk away. Definitely not the type of service I was expecting.
author: Olivia E.

description: I went to Eclipse with my girlfriend for a quick nightcap on Valentine's Day. The food, drinks and service were all great! The highlight was really the atmosphere - comfortable seating, good music and an inviting environment.
author: Adam E.

description:
After wandering on the Embarcadero to soak in the gorgeous views of the bay (and the frigidly cold weather), my friends and I found ourselves in search of alcohol to warm our bodies.  Unfortunately, casual bar options are apparently slim by the Ferry Building at 10:00 on a Friday night, so we opted for the Hyatt's hotel bar out of convenience.  Maybe next time, we'll search a little harder.

After grabbing a table, I ordered a Diamond Gin and Tonic for my first round.  Now, if you know what makes it "diamond", please feel free to let me know.  Other than running for $12, I'm not too sure what sets it apart from a regular sort of gin and tonic - it was pretty average.  After that, we just switched to beer for our second/last round to keep it light (didn't pay for that one, so not sure how much those cost).

Feeling a little hungry, we also decided to order a snack to split for the table.  I'm not sure if this was the exact name, but we ended up ordering the Olde English Club Sandwich (turkey, bacon, fried egg, lettuce, and tomato) that came with a side of seasoned fries.  The sandwich was actually pretty decent compared to most I've had (I credit the fried egg), but I think the fries were the winner.  It's hard not to like crispy french fries (especially with a drink in hand), but it's harder to say that it was worth it when it was $15.

Service is pretty mediocre - they got the job done, but could certainly be better...and faster.  Once we were ready to go, it took quite some time for our check to be brought to us, and just as long for them to bring back the tab for the slip to be signed.  Despite about a half dozen staff members just kind of hanging out at the bar together, it seems like no one was able to help our table table except for our specific waitress, who would disappear from time to time.  Talk about inefficient.

Situated in the lobby of the Hyatt, the relaxed ambiance and attractive decor are the only redeeming qualities.  Considering options are a little light in the financial district area at night, it's not terrible if you're a tourist or in the area, but certainly not a place to go out of the way for.  Especially considering they close pretty damn early for a bar.
author: Mike L.

description: Had a perfect Manhattan, it was excellent! The newly remodeled Eclipse bar is awesome.  They spent some serious money to get it to look as great as it does. Big screen TVs, probably more than  25 seats at the over-sized bar and really cool seating pods made out of large wine  casks.  Food was great and it wasn't too crowded.
author: ken C.

description: We arrived late from the east coast so decided to eat at the hotel and we were pleasantly surprised. The flatbread was generously sized and tasty. My friend's sandwich was also very good and the sweet potato fries were crispy and nicely seasoned.
author: Nancy S.

description: We had recently stayed at Hyatt at Embarcadero to Celebrate our 11th Wedding Anniversary. The 1st stop in our Adventure was the Happy Hour at the Eclipse Bar in the Atrium of the Hyatt. They had plenty of seating and a couple of Booths. I ordered a Mojito and started off with Chips and Salsa, and the Pita Chips Hummus for the Happy Hour price of $4.00. The drink was about $10 which is not on the Menu. Wifey had a Corona which was more reasonable at the price of $3. The Server was Friendly and the drink was okay, but definitely not strong. We also ordered Hot Wings and they were really good. I liked that the sauces Bleu Cheese and Wing Sauce were served on the side. The place was busy for a Friday but the Server was quick and efficient. I will remember to stop by for a quick drink if we are ever in the neighborhood again.
author: Robert R.

description: I've stayed here easily a dozen times for work, and while the food is actually pretty good, the service is universally abysmal. I'm writing this in the Eclipse bar after having waited literally 30 minutes for someone to take our drink order. At least three servers walked past us in that time and averted their eyes. The servers are always very nice, but never in much of a hurry.
author: David B T.

description: Nice atmosphere, pretty expensive. I liked the lights hanging from the ceiling!
author: Rich P.

description: The grilled cheese apple sandwich with avocado and bacon is greattt! The service was very friendly both the waitress and the guy at the entrance (welcome-person.. What are those called..? Host?) who helped us get on the wifi :) great place for a meeting. Great atmosphere.
author: Rianne O.

description: Wow! The Avocado Toast is my favorite--grilled sourdough, avocado,roasted tomato, poached egg, herb salad. It is so fresh and such a healthy way to start the day! Catch breakfast here and you won't be disappointed.
author: Ashley B.

description: Who knew this cute quirky bar was hidden inside the Hyatt Regency? Definitely worth an after work visit now that it's been fully renovated, lots of cozy nooks to sit in and good specialty cocktail selection.  Creative design with a menu to match.  Do not miss the truffle fries.
author: Emma M.

description: Love the lights from the celing. The drinks were good, very tasty. I had the Rasberry lemon drop and the cucumber martini. Both very refreshing, great summer drinks to beat this heat. It would be better if they had some younger bartenders. The bartenders were older and were all speaking in spanish so who knows if they were talking about their customers. Also if it was a smaller more intimate space. Just feels huge space, with one tiny bar in the middle. I am a fan of hotel bars, if I'm in the area I would come back
author: Melissa B.

description: Wow... What a great experience! Awesome service, excellent food ...a truly great experience!
author: Lysa L.

description: Regarding breakfast: The food is not good, especially for the price. The hotel is fairly nice, but there are several great restaurants in the area for about half to two-thirds the cost. So do yourself a favor - save some money eating MUCH better food while enjoying some nice scenery in this beautiful area of the city.
author: Omar J.

description:
I want to talk about our cool waiter, but I know nothing identifying about him besides his almond skin color. He was personable, made a joke that elicited some hearty laughs, and even stole some chips from the Hyatt because the kitchen was closed. Then we watched some awesome college football on what must have been a 15-foot high projector screen.

If you stop here, get the same waiter, sit on one of the luxurious couches, and get beers, this is a five star review.

But we had cocktails, and oh wow they were awful. Watery and sugary...I don't even like most liquor and I knew they were bad. Poor waiter doesn't deserve this two star review but this is the most honest I can be :(

Also, they close at 12 midnight, which is kind of early. Oh and don't come here expecting to park cheaply, valet is $57 for the night. (!)
author: Ralph L.

description:
Great service, horrible food.

The food is crap and it's way overpriced, even for the location.  We had a very nice waitress who was honest in her recommendations, but the food will be keeping me from returning.
author: Otto D.

description:
My Auntie took me here for lunch the other day.  The restaurant was not packed at all during the lunch hour.  

The service was OK.  Kinda slow and lazy.  

I got the Cobb Salad ($16.00).  It had grilled chicken breast, tomato, egg, bacon, avocado and blue cheese with mustard dressing.  The salad was pretty good, except the chicken breast was a little bit dry.   Everything was so fresh and the portion was huge. 

If you have plenty of time and want a quite, relax and pricy lunch, you can give it a try.
author: Liza T.

description:
It's been around 15 years since I last came to this location for a drink after work.  Finally, given the need to get some things off my mind and that I need to do some night work nearby, I decided to relive those days. :)

My drinks of choice: two Bloody Mary's.  I don't know much about prices for cocktails in most places, but $10 may be pricy though not unexpected because of this being a Hyatt Hotel lobby lounge location. Here it is enjoyable to sit back and enjoy the drinks and, at the same time watch tv on the giant TV (they had the Giants game on that evening, so that was a plus for a fan like me), or enjoy watching the Hyatt Hotel environment especially since it's built so that you can see all the upper floors circling the perimeter and on up to the roof.

As described elsewhere, service could have been better.  There were many opportunities for a staff earlier on to come by and ask me if I wished to order something.  I ended up waiting for a while and had to consider flagging someone down.
author: H K.

description:
REVIEW FOR BREAKFAST BUFFET

We were staying at the Hyatt and had the chance to eat at Eclipse one morning. The spread is sizeable; the "cold" section has oatmeal, yogurt, parfaits, lox, cold cut platter, cheese (brie and feta on that day), an assortment of croissants and muffins, toast, bagels, and fresh fruit. The "hot" section has your standard bacon, sausage, eggs, hash, breakfast potatoes, and an omelet station. I found myself satisfied with at almost every item, and impressed especially with the parfaits (put fresh berries with mascarpone cheese together and you've won my heart over instantly), bacon (it's hard to cook bacon well, especially in bulk; this was thick and cirspy), and eggs (again - it's hard to make good scrambled eggs, and these were perfectly creamy). The quality of the sausage is lower than the other items, in my opinion (chunky and a weird, almost artificial taste), and I think I can make a better omelet since these were overcooked. Still, the majority of the items were fresh and well executed.  I like my breakfasts. This one pleased me.

(A word about price - the whole breakfast spread is $23.95 but you can just get the cold items (the continental breakfast) for $15 - they don't advertise this.)
author: Clarice W.

description: Banana walnut pancakes were so fluffy and good.  Fast service helped me get to my meeting on time!
author: Jenna W.

description: Service painfully slow.  Just ordering a drink took forever. The happy hour appetizers are reasonably priced. The cocktail menu had a few unique selection.  Just don't be in a rush.
author: Nina M.

description: Average service. Average food.  Clam chowder bread bowl was pretty good.
author: Kauai H.

description:
I'm reviewing this for Thanksgiving Dinner (very late, I know, but better late than never).

Solid 4.5 stars for our waiter's service. The waiter was extremely communicative, helpful and friendly, and very attentive given the fact that there were quite a few diners and their families crowding the hotel for Thanksgiving.

Our Thanksgiving dinner choices consisted of pumpkin squash soup (with toasted seed garnish), salad, and turkey with traditional sides (mashed potato and green beans). The squash soup was delicious, one of the better we've had. Salad was all right but the combination of flavors and textures did not come together in my mouth. The turkey was very good - tender and not dry - but it was the stuffing that stole the show.

The only complaint I had was that they'd run out of our dessert choices, but as I'm a health-conscious eater that didn't matter quite as much. Also the server (a different one from our waiter) should not have brought each dish out immediately while we were still eating. They should have at least employed a dish warmer as I think it was the entree or soup that got cold while we were still finishing the course before it. Minus a star for that.
author: Kit A.

description:
Breakfast review. Had the egg white special (want to say it was the "Joe's Omelet")

Service was average. The omelet was average. The space was interesting and huge feeling given the massively high ceilings. You paid for it given this omelet was worth half of what I paid for it as food alone. This is very much an average place for breakfast, nothing special or unique here from what I can tell or from my one experience.
author: Ravi A.

description: I had a couple of Hendrick's Gin Martinis here last Friday as I awaited my wife who came into the City on BART.   It's comfortable and they have a good selection of spirits.   I was quite disappointed, though, with their pathetic selection of appetizers.   I opted for the Chips with Hummus mostly because it was the best choice out of 3.   Still, if you just want a drink, this is a nice place where you won't have to fight your way to the bar.
author: David O.

description:
This place is a definite eye candy that allures you in with its beauty...only to largely disappoint with very mediocre food and service.

I ordered the "Kobe Sliders" which comes with a side of fries for $15.

The plate came with 2 sliders. The bun was nice, buttery and soft, but what should have been the highlight (the meat!) was no where near as tender as "kobe" SHOULD be. 

The fries were decent; nicely crispped and salted and they give you a whole lot served up in a decorative "newspaper" coned cup. But, the dipping sauce greatly confused me: sweet chili-esque sauce es no bueno! Did more damage than anything.

The service was average; efficient, but lacking personality and attentiveness unless called upon.

The only memorable part of this place besides the streaming twinkling lights above is the freshly cut nicely crusted bread: they cut it out on the main dining floor (so you can tell its fresh) served with a sun dried tomato tapenade spread drizzled with olive oil. This is complimentary...upon request.

All in all, if you're a guest at the Hyatt here, you will DEFINITELY find better venturing outside of the hotel.
author: Gail N.

description:
Very slow service. They bring you coffee and then no one comes to to take your order.

The food was subpar at best and expensive.  

If you are in a rush, then don't eat here.  If you are on an expense account and want to whack your company, eat here!

The bottom line.... Don't eat at this place.
author: David S.

description: Dine About Town lunch not that amazing (not a lot of options).   Service impeccable, nice atmosphere, good for lunch dates.  Would not repeat Dine About Town here but for business meetings ... yes.
author: Dianne L.

description: What a pleasant surprise. Very very very not bad hotel food. Decent drink prices and an interesting dish in the lamb meatballs. I'm FOR it.
author: Lee H.

description:
Romantic place, good food, service was a little slow, but we were not in a hurry.  
Then while we each had a fork in our hands and a mouth full of food, they ask if they can take our plates!?!  rather pushy!
It's not cheap... $60 (with tip) for a casual lunch for two is a bit outrageous, so I don't think we'll be going back.
author: C J.

description:
There are two kinds of food: hotel food and non-hotel food. Most hotel food is dreadful. In the hotel food world, I found Eclipse to be AMAZINGLY delicious!! While staying for a long weekend at the Hyatt (my second home) I had the following: 

Hamburger on Oat Bun - juicy, flavorful and yummy! 
Bacon / cheddar omelet - excellent with a single pancake :) 
Wharf Seafood Salad - delicious and rivals Grotto No 9 for much less money! 
French Onion Soup - by far the best FOS I've ever eaten (and I've eaten a lot of FOS!)
